author: By Kurt Soller
title: For Pride Month, Eight Stories About Queer Power and Defiance
description: Essential reading from T’s archive, including pieces on how L.G.B.T.Q. culture has re-envisioned the worlds of food, art and entertainment.
content: Stonewall was a riot. This has become the de facto slogan to describe the series of early-summer 1969 demonstrations that took place in front of New York City’s Stonewall Inn, the gay bar that became a battleground for the movement that catalyzed L.G.B.T.Q. rights in this country. Indeed, this historic rebellion is the reason we celebrate Pride Month each June. But as America rages on — against an uncured pandemic as well as its aftereffects, and for justice following the deaths of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and others at the hands of police — that phrase, “Stonewall was a riot,” has taken on new resonance: It’s an assertion that fighting, not partying, is the root of our story. And this year, as many join in protests chanting “Black lives matter,” we are reminded that the Stonewall liberation was led by trans women of color, including Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera, two activists whom city officials decided last year to honor with a monument, after decades of progress being too often attributed to mostly white gay men.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Da 5 Bloods’ Review: Black Lives Mattered in Vietnam, Too
description: Spike Lee’s new joint is an anguished, funny, violent argument with and about American history, with an unforgettable performance from Delroy Lindo at its heart.
content: Spike Lee’s career can be described as a lover’s quarrel with American movies — and with America, too. As he has demonstrated his oligarchy of established genres (the biopic, the musical, the cop movie, the combat picture, and so on), he has also reinvented them, pointing out blind spots and filling in gaps. His critique of Hollywood’s long history of ignoring and distorting black lives has altered the way we look at movies. His attempts to expand the frame and correct the record have changed the course of the cultural mainstream.

content: As protests over police brutality swept the country in recent weeks and major retailers posted messages of solidarity with black Americans on social media, Aurora James, a creative director in Brooklyn, asked herself if she actually felt that those brands were standing with her as a black woman and business owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Modigliani Expert Says a Nonprofit Is Holding His Research ‘Hostage’
description: Marc Restellini, an art historian, is fighting the Wildenstein Plattner Institute over the ownership of a research archive he spent decades compiling.
content: For more than three decades, Marc Restellini’s life has been very much about his study of Amedeo Modigliani, the Italian painter known for his elongated, slender faces and figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: George Floyd’s Brother Pleads With Congress: ‘Make It Stop’
description: Philonise Floyd, the star witness at a House hearing on Democrats’ policing bill, called for Congress to “stop the pain” caused by the killings of black men at the hands of the police.
content: WASHINGTON — Philonise Floyd, whose brother’s death in police custody has inspired two weeks of sprawling protests across the country, made an impassioned plea to Congress on Wednesday to enact sweeping changes to law enforcement in America to address police brutality and systemic racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: LeBron James and Other Stars Form a Voting Rights Group
description: “This is the time for us to finally make a difference,” the N.B.A. superstar said of the new group, which will aim to protect African-Americans’ voting rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The N.B.A. superstar LeBron James and a group of other prominent black athletes and entertainers are starting a new group aimed at protecting African-Americans’ voting rights, seizing on the widespread fury against racial injustice that has fueled worldwide protests to amplify their voices in this fall’s presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Reid J. Epstein
title: Jon Ossoff Wins Democratic Senate Primary in Georgia
description: A day after the state’s elections descended into confusion, Mr. Ossoff, a 33-year-old Democrat, emerged as the party’s challenger to the Republican incumbent, Senator David Perdue.
content: ATLANTA — Jon Ossoff, the 33-year-old Georgia Democrat who earned national attention in 2017 with a spirited but unsuccessful congressional race in the Atlanta suburbs, won his party’s nomination in a race for a Senate seat on Wednesday, a day after the state’s elections descended into chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bee Shapiro
title: Teyana Taylor Keeps Her Skin Care Natural and Her Brows Defined
description: The singer and dancer loves her skin. Here’s why.
content: The singer-songwriter-choreographer Teyana Taylor isn’t letting a pandemic slow down the release of her third studio album, called simply “The Album,” which is out this month). Ms. Taylor, 29, isn’t piling on cosmetics during these difficult times. Instead she’s taking a more relaxed approach to beauty. Find out how she’s doing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Judge to ICE: Don’t Ambush Immigrants at New York Courthouses
description: For years, federal officers have been taking undocumented immigrants into custody when they come to state courts. A judge said the practice was illegal.
content: One undocumented immigrant who had been robbed at gunpoint refused to testify in Brooklyn because he feared federal immigration enforcement officers would detain him if he went to court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Demands CNN Retract a Poll, as OANN Teases a Rosier View
description: The president’s campaign urged CNN to apologize for a poll that showed him well behind Joe Biden. Soon after, One America News suggested a more favorable survey was on the way.
content: President Trump’s re-election campaign has sued several news outlets for coverage it deemed unflattering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs and Text by Alex Potter
title: When Nowhere Feels Safe, Finding Sanctuary on the Drive Home
description: Healthcare workers have few spaces of sanctuary, between risk at work and anxiety at home that our loved ones could catch the disease from us.

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: New York Philharmonic Cancels Fall Season
description: The lost performances will cost the orchestra approximately $9 million in ticket revenue.
content: With the number of coronavirus cases down sharply in New York, the city began a gradual reopening this week. But in yet another sign that the full resumption of cultural life is still far off, the New York Philharmonic announced on Wednesday that it was canceling its fall season.
source.name: The New York Times
